title_sort: walt whitman to william sloane kennedy, john burroughs, and richard maurice bucke, 25 february 1887
title: Walt Whitman to William Sloane Kennedy, John Burroughs, and Richard Maurice Bucke, 25 February 1887
text: Camden,Feb. 25, '87, P. M.Am sitting here by the window in the little front room down stairs, well wrapt up—for though bright & sunny it is a cold freezing day—have had my dinner (of rare stewed oysters, some toasted graham bread & a cup of tea—relished all)—am about as usual—ups & downs—had rather a bad day yesterday—lay on the lounge most of the day—now better—the worst is my enforced house-imprisonment, sometimes two weeks at a time—Spirits & heart though mainly gay, which is the best half of the battle—Love & comfort to you, my friends—your wives & all—Write often as you can—(monotony is now the word of my life)—Walt WhitmanWhen read send to John Burroughs, West Park, Ulster County, New York. Walt Whitman to William Sloane Kennedy, John Burroughs, and Richard Maurice Bucke, 25 February 1887
